Award.AwardTitle: Novel Biomaterials for Liver Tissue Engineering

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1033525
Janorkar

This proposal engineers a novel 3-D liver tissue model. The first objective is the design and characterization of a new class of chemo-biologically synthesized copolymers that can be used to induce formation of 3-D in vitro liver tissue models. The second objective is to take the elastin-like polypeptides and charged polyelectrolytes (ELP-PE) copolymers with the best charge/adhesion/morphological properties and investigate 3-D hepatocyte spheroid formation with a detailed kinetic and biochemical analysis of liver specific function. In addition to creating new materials, the work will study the fundamental relationships between ELP-PE properties and biological function of liver cells and provide insight for future liver engineering and drug testing liver systems.

The applicant will actively recruit minority students into his laboratory and include graduate, DMD, and undergraduates as well as high school students. There is an extensive plan for the involvement of minority students directly in research by collaborating with a historically black college and by visiting the rural areas and schools of a disadvantaged state.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Liver diseases affect 1 in every 5 Americans and may affect many more in future. Developing models of liver tissue will greatly further the basic science research that may allow scientists to test various hypotheses, study the altered cellular biology due to the disease, and therefore, facilitate development of therapies. We followed a novel tissue engineering approach to create the three-dimensional liver cell culture model based on a global hypothesis that smart copolymers consisting of an adherent/biocompatible component (the elastin-like polypeptide) and a non-adherent/charged component (the polyelectrolyte) will demonstrate elevated efficacy in three-dimensional hepatocyte spheroid formation and achieve long-term culture conditions. Key outcomes related to this project have included: (1) Investigation of the effects of various reaction conditions on synthesis of these copolymers, (2) Investigation of the effects of various culture conditions on liver cell behavior to identify the optimal surface coating concentrations that will produce spheroids with uniform size distribution and minimum occurrence of over-grown spheroids, (3) In total, we have formulated and characterized 36 compositions of copolymer coatings and successfully tested them for cell culture, and (4) These results have led to the publication of 7 journal articles, 3 peer-reviewed conference proceedings, and more than 20 oral/poster presentations to date.

This project provided opportunities for several students to participate in research. Two graduate students, three professional (D.M.D.) students, seven undergraduate students, and one high-school student have worked on this project. The graduate students enjoyed opportunities to mentor the professional and undergraduate students. Additionally, through the Undergraduate and Professional Student Training in Advanced Research Techniques (UPSTART) program and the Summer Undergraduate Research Experience (SURE) program for student research, undergraduate students from the local colleges and universities were trained in design and successful implementation of a research project through a didactic seminar series, hands-on laboratory research, and research presentations. Through outreach activities, undergraduate students were made aware of research activities and graduate education opportunities through various presentations. The research team continues to participate in an outreach event highlighting the UMMC graduate programs at the Mississippi Children's Museum.


Last Modified: 10/30/2015
Modified by: Amol V Janorkar
